title: Asia shares tumble as Hong Kong unrest, Argentine peso crash unnerve investors
text: Asian shares slumped on Tuesday as fears about a drawn out Sino-U.S. trade war, protests in Hong Kong and a crash in Argentina's peso currency drove investors to safe harbors like bonds, gold, and the Japanese yen.

title: Asia shares slip as Hong Kong unrest, Argentine peso crash rattle investors
text: Asian shares fell on Tuesday as fears about a drawn out Sino-U.S. trade war, protests in Hong Kong and a crash in Argentina's peso currency drove investors to safe harbors like bonds, gold, and the yen.

title: The economy is not falling into a recession, but the slowdown stocks are working, Cramer says
text: "The day-to-day action is going to favor the slowdown stocks and wreak havoc for the industrials, the technology stocks, and worst of all the financials," Jim Cramer says.

title: Yields and Stocks Resume Slide
text: Stocks tumbled (again) on rising economic concerns, bond yields approached new lows, and the China large-cap ETF fell to key support.

title: Long-time bull turns bearish while these market worries persist
text: Jonathan Golub, Credit Suisse, says this is the most bearish he's been in a while. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Tim Seymour, Brian Kelly, Dan Nathan and Mark Tepper.

title: Stocks slammed as rates tumble
text: Big Wall Street firms are raising a red flag on trade tensions. So what's next? With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Tim Seymour, Brian Kelly, Dan Nathan and Mark Tepper.

title: Hedge Funds Go All In on Gold
text: Gold prices are already at the highest in more than six years, and Goldman Sachs Group Inc.and Citigroup Inc. predict bullion could climb about 6% to $1,600 an ounce in as little as six months. Money managers are going all in, raising their wagers on a rally to the highest since 2016.

title: Mother of all short-covering rallies for bond market: David Rosenberg
text: David Rosenberg of Gluskin Sheff and Jim Paulsen of The Leuthold Group join CNBC's "Closing Bell" to discuss the day's market sell-off.

title: Wall Street Indexes Fall More than 1%
text: U.S. stocks were in the red on Monday as protests in Hong Kong and Macri's adverse voting in Argentina's PASO made for a weak session.

text: In "Charting Futures: This Week,” Bloomberg Intelligence's Mike McGlone discusses the technicals on corn and soybeans. We also take a look at today's news on oil and gold.

title: Look at good companies with good earnings taken down by market: Kevin Hincks
text: Kevin Hincks, senior equity strategist at TD Ameritrade, joins CNBC's "Closing Bell" to discuss what he's watching as markets pull back for trade the close.

title: Goldman Sachs cuts growth forecast as trade war fears intensify
text: Cornell Capital Partner, Anne Berry discusses the impact the U.S.  China trade war will have on growth.

title: Dow ends nearly 400 points lower as falling Treasury yields underline economic jitters
text: Stocks fell sharply Monday, appearing to take a cue from a slump in Treasury yields that reflected mounting worries about the economic outlook and geopolitical concerns.

title: Wall St sells off amid geopolitical worries
text: U.S. stocks dropped more than 1% on Monday in a broad sell-off as simmering geopolitical tensions spooked equity investors and drove a bond market rally while the protracted U.S.-China trade war stoked fears of an impending recession.

title: I think yields are pretty close to their lows: Tony Dwyer
text: Tony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Canaccord Genuity, joins the "Closing Bell" team to discuss what he thinks is happening in the markets and what investors should do next.

title: Is Bitcoin Entering The Slope Of Enlightenment?
text: Looking at clues from consumer insights data, and the recent price action in Bitcoin, it’s clear that the public’s interest in cryptocurrency is getting some wind back in its sails.  But where do we currently stand in the hype cycle for crypto?

title: Wall Street sell-off as fresh global concerns add to US-China trade war fears
text: US stock markets have fallen sharply as a cocktail of global concerns from protests in Hong Kong to elections in Argentina added to deepening worries about the US-China trade war.

text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team UBS's call on the 10-year yield with Kevin Giddis of Raymond James.

title: Here's what happens if the 10-year Treasury note inverts
text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team is joined by Jim Iuorio of TJM Institutional Services to discuss what the 10-year treasury note is signaling.

title: Bond market close to sending biggest recession signal yet
text: The bond market could soon send its loudest recession warning yet, if the closely watched 10-year yield falls below the 2-year note yield.

title: Fintech Debt Investors Follow Equity Dollars Into Latin America
text: Fintech firms in Latin America are having a moment with the equity investing titans of the world, and debt investors are taking note.

title: Trade War Worries Will Keep Brent ~$60 Unless OPEC Makes Draconian Oil Output Cuts
text: Oil market will see a continued, sustained lower price environment unless the cartel ups its cuts by a further, and somewhat unlikely, 1 million bpd.

title: Morgan Stanley analysts say Fed to cut U.S. rates in September
text: Morgan Stanley  analysts said on Monday that they now expect the U.S. Federal Reserve to cut rates in September and then again in October.

title: The Fed's Struggle To End Yield Curve Inversion
text: Why the Fed may not to end yield-curve inversion by cutting rates this year.

text: CNBC's "Power Team" team discusses how markets are trading with Bill Stone of Avalon Advisors and Eddie Perkin of Eaton Vance.

title: We will get a trade deal in the long-term, says former NATO commander
text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team discusses global hotspots with James Stavridis, former NATO Supreme Allied Commander Admiral, and Michelle Caruso-Cabrera, CNBC contributor.

title: Why We Might Already Be in a Bear Market
text: Since Jan. 2018, the S&P 500 is roughly flat, while 80% of global equity markets and also most U.S. stocks are down, Morgan Stanley finds.

title: Investors, 'starved for returns,' flood private markets in search of high-growth opportunities
text: Many global investors are turning toward Silicon Valley instead of Wall Street in search of returns.

title: Hong Kong situation remains far from worst case scenario, says Economist editor
text: James Miles, The Economist China editor, joins 'The Exchange' to discuss the continuing unrest in Hong Kong and what the worst case scenario could be.

title: Dow falls more 1% in afternoon trade as 10-year Treasury on the verge of new 52-week low
text: U.S. stocks deepened their losses Monday afternoon as government bond yields plumbed fresh lows, highlighting growing worries about geopolitical risks that have buffeted Wall Street.

title: Rely less on ETFs and more on stock positions: BMO's Brian Belski
text: Barry James, James Investment Research, and Brian Belski, BMO Capital Markets, join 'The Exchange' to discuss the state of the stock market as it faces its 3rd straight weekly drop.

title: Gold resumes rally to start week, adds to move above $1,500, as stocks slide amid global anxieties
text: Gold futures finished higher on Monday as geopolitical fears drove investors to the perceived safety of so-called havens including bonds and gold.

title: Hong Kong protests: Why markets are getting rattled
text: John Hancock Investments's Matt Miskin discusses the turmoil in Hong Kong  and the impact on the U.S.

title: People giving up on stocks despite nearing all-time highs: Josh Brown
text: The 'Fast Money Halftime Report' team discuss the mid-day markets on concerns regarding tariffs, earnings and the economy.

title: Market Bull Ed Yardeni: Don't Fear The 'Most Hated Bull Market Of All Time'
text: The decade-long bull run in U.S. stocks has some investors concerned the end is near and a recession is on the horizon in the next two years.

title: Wall Street sees even more Fed rate cuts ahead with Morgan Stanley predicting a return to zero
text: Economists now see the likelihood of three quarter-point reductions before the end of the year, along with multiple moves in 2020.

title: Oil steadies as Saudi, Kuwait signals offset demand fears
text: Oil prices were little changed on Monday as expectations that major producers would continue to reduce global supplies faced worries about sluggish crude demand growth due to the U.S.-China trade war.

title: With Yields Sinking Everywhere, Gold Just Hit New All-Time Highs.
text: Gold headed for its best week in nearly two months as the value of negative-yielding debt touched a new record of $15 trillion. The 10-year Treasury yield fell below 2 percent, pushing gold above $1,500 an ounce for the first time since September 2013.
